Award.AwardTitle: Characterization and Modeling of Multimechanistic Flow Behaviors from Nano- to Macro-scale in Shale Matrix

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Liu, Shimin
Proposal Number: 1438398


The focus of the proposed research in to study gas flow in tight pores, such as those found in shale formations. Flow, adsorption, desorption, slippage and deformation of the surrounding rock are proposed to be studied with both experiments and theory. This is a timely research project with implications in an area of critical importance for the economy and the energy production of the U.S. Results for the proposed work would be of benefit to the oil and gas production industry, to public policy makers and to carbon management entities. Accurate prediction of the flow of gases in shales is also important for developing CO2 sequestration strategies.

The goal of the proposed research is to advance fluid dynamics knowledge for flow through tight shales -- critical for shale gas production. There are multiple physical mechanisms that affect the flow, such as sorption, diffusion, advection, and sorption-induced organic matter deformation with the progressive decrease in reservoir pressure as the gas is produce. Experiments are proposed to quantify the characteristics of the flow and the interactions with the sorption-induced deformation of the pore organic matter. A series of laboratory and theoretical studies will be conducted that will include: pore structure characterization using small-angle neutron scattering (SANS) and ultra-small-angle neutron scattering (USANS) instruments at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), which will provide reliable pore architecture for the subsequent flow measurement and modeling studies, sorption and diffusivity measurement at in situ conditions, sorption-induced deformation measurement, and apparent permeability measurement. The modeling effort would result to an apparent permeability model by considering sorption, diffusion and sorption-induced deformation, and would be validated by the measured experimental data. The educational plan centers on an interdisciplinary educational experience that will be offered to the graduate and undergraduate students involved. Educational efforts will be leveraged through the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) Program, which was funded by NSF to encourage underrepresented minority students in the STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among all energy sources, natural gas is considered as abundant, reliable and with reduced carbon content over conventional fossil fuels. Recently, hydrocarbon exploration and recovery in the US has focused heavily on unconventional plays – shale gas in particular. As of January 2017, shale gas contributes about half of the US domestic gas production and has helped the US meet its entire domestic demand. Despite modest gas prices in recent years, production grows continuously and shale gas is expected to account for two-thirds of US domestic gas production by 2040. Shale gas reservoirs are also known as unconventional reservoirs. In gas shales, the gas is generated in place and the shale acts as both the source rock and the reservoir. Methane is stored in shale in three different states: (1) adsorbed gas on kerogen, (2) free gas within pores and fractures and (3) dissolved gas in kerogen.

Despite considerable inroads in the development of advanced technologies (e.g., horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing) for shale gas production, over the past two decades, the pace of understanding and modeling of flow behaviors has lagged far behind the implementation of technology for recovery. Gas transport dynamics in shale remains poorly understood with many specificities left unexplained. Field statistics show that production rates from a large percentage of producing wells decreases by as much as 70% after just one year of production; recovery factors of less than 15% of the original gas in place are very low compared to conventional reservoirs; produced gas in the early-years is mainly the free gas, with negligible amounts of gas desorbed from the organic matrix.

The questions that guide this study are: “What are the key mechanisms of gas transport through nano-pore structure under reservoir-like pressure and temperature conditions? and how do different flow mechanisms contribute to the overall gas transport during long-term well production?”. To address these questions, a series of multiscale, multiphysics, interdisciplinary laboratory and theoretical studies have been conducted including: Laboratory Experimentation: (a) pore structure characterization using state-of-the-art small-angle neutron scattering (SANS) and ultra-small-angle neutron scattering (USANS) instruments at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), which provide reliable pore architecture for the subsequent flow measurement and modeling studies, (b) sorption and diffusivity measurements under in situ conditions, (c) sorption-induced deformation measurements, (d) apparent permeability measurement; Modeling and Analysis: (e) modeling sorption capacity and diffusivity, (f) modeling sorption induced shale matrix strain, and (g) modeling of apparent permeability with considerations of sorption, diffusion and sorption-induced deformation.

This work is the first attempt to study the nano-scale pore accessibility of shale using in situ SANS measurements. A theoretical pore accessibility model has been proposed based on neutron scattering intensities recovered under both vacuum and zero average contract (ZAC) conditions. The experiments, using deuterated methane (CD4) at low Q-values for Marcellus shales, show that scattering intensity decreases with increasing gas pressure. The results also suggest that shale matrix pore accessibility is a size-dependent parameter and the fraction of pores accessible to methane decreases with a decrease in pore size from 80 nm to 15 nm. We also find that the shale matrix swells with methane gas adsorption due to the surface energy decrease and we observe a Langmuir-type strain increase with continuous gas adsorption. The shale matrix swelling will ultimately modify the shale matrix porosity and the micro-scale fracture networks present therein, and eventually change the apparent permeability of the shale matrix.

Our experimental results demonstrate that gas transport in shale matrix does not always fall within the continuum flow regime described by Darcy’s law. Rather, a considerable portion of this transport is sporadic and irregular when the mean free path of gas becomes comparable to the prevailing pore scale. Nonlinear processes drive non-Darcy flow components like gas sorption, gas slippage, and diffusion that occur throughout gas recovery in shale reservoirs. A new permeability model with pressure-dependent weighting factors is proposed to describe gas flow. The proposed model predicts and models the “U-shaped” permeability trends caused by fluid dynamics and geomechanical effects with the model validated against experimental data.

This project spans both research and education aspects, including multidisciplinary undergraduate and graduate student training and multi- and cross-scale fractal pore characterization. A more realistic understanding of gas transport dynamics in nanopore networks gained through this project provides fundamental guidance for the long-term optimization of gas production from shale gas reservoirs. Such knowledge will aid field engineers and operators in making more data-enabled decisions during the production process.
